docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of those who lost family members in the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the World Trade Center, and of their lives since. They were written by Cara Buckley, Glenn Collins, Anthony DePalma, Robin Finn, Jan Hoffman, Tina Kelley, N. R. Kleinfield and Andy Newman. Their stories appear alongside photographs of the victims. With the exception of Ms. Buckley, the writers interviewed families they had spoken to five years ago. The families were chosen by the reporters; some who were contacted chose not to participate. STEPHEN KEVIN TOMPSETT Worrying Enough for Two For Dorry Tompsett it is a daily struggle, trying to make sure her daughter does not mother her too much.

headline.main: Getting Past the Pain of 9/11, In Steps Both Big and Small

docs.abstract: Family remembrances of some of Sept 11, 2001, terrorist attack victims; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Departure of a Pragmatist'' (editorial, Sept. 8) concludes that the Medicare administrator, Mark McClellan, ''seems mostly to have succeeded'' in launching the administration's limited and inefficient drug benefit because of an 80 percent satisfaction rating with the new program. This overlooks the goal of insurance: to pool the resources of the many to protect the few.
docs.abstract: Roger Hickey letter holds that while Medicare adminstrator Mark McClellan is not responsible for confusing drug benefit program, his agency could have done more to protect people with costliest medication needs (Sept 8 editorial)
